awd_titl_txt: Building Cyber Capacity in the Northwest and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
Whatcom Community College (WCC) proposes to expand upon its cybersecurity programs and workforce capacity-building efforts through a trio of interrelated efforts that support the student pipeline from high school through college and university, including online learning. The project will build the pipeline through high school camps and competitions that offer mentorship opportunities for college students, opportunities for high school students to earn college credit, and exposure to industry, with the ultimate goal of embedding programs in regional high schools for maximum impact. WCC has been designated by the National Security Agency and the Department of Homeland Security as a National Center of Academic Excellence in cybersecurity. It is also the lead institution for Cyber Watch West, a regional center for cybersecurity education funded by the NSF's Advanced Technological Education program. The proposed efforts will leverage these projects and prepare students for emerging topics in key cybersecurity industry sectors including industrial control systems, secure cloud computing, mobile technology, and web development. 

The goals of this project are to:  (1) develop and offer an online bachelor of applied science degree in networking, which will include security-infused coursework, embedded certificates, and remote lab accessibility; (2) develop an upper division support/navigator program for students pursuing their programs at WCC or at nearby Western Washington University; and (3) leverage current cybersecurity camps for high school students by including participation in  the national high school competition Cyber Patriot. The project will provide employers in both industry and government with qualified networking and cybersecurity professionals to meet the workforce demands. It will offer college credit to high school students successfully completing the cybersecurity camp and will ensure industry participation in curriculum and program development. The program emphasizes study and soft skills using a human-centered design approach that focuses on the individual needs of each student and emphasizes interpersonal skills, critical thinking, and customer service.

por.por_cntn:
Grant title: Building Cyber Capacity in the Northwest and Beyond

This project expanded upon previous Whatcom Community College (WCC) computer information systems/cybersecurity workforce capacity building initiatives through a trio of interrelated efforts that support the student pipeline from high school through higher education and include online programs:

1. Develop and offer an online bachelor of applied science (BAS) degree in IT networking,which will run in parallel with an in-person program, and include security-infused coursework, embedded certificates, and remote accessibility through NETLAB+;

2. Develop an upper division support/navigator program for students pursuing either the BAS program at WCC or the Computer Information Systems Security bachelor's degree at nearby Western Washington University (WWU); and

3. Leverage current cybersecurity camps for high school students engaging more students in the cybersecurity pipeline at an earlier age.

 GOAL 1 - Implement an in-person BAS degree in IT Networking with a strong cybersecurity focus.

WCC completed the development of the BAS degree and realized in-person program enrollments in fall 2017, renaming it to IT Networking - Cybersecurity. As of August 2020, the BAS enrolled 79 students and graduated 20; 55 students were enrolled as of fall 2020. CISCO networking course were strengthened and a new web development certificate was added.

 

GOAL 2 - Develop an online version of the BAS degree with remote access for lab work through NETLAB+.   NETLAB was implemented as were other applications (VMWare and Microsoft), and lecture content was moved to Canvas. Instructors expanded office hours and use Canvas tools and other online tools allowing students to complete course work remotely. WCC's accreditors approved the online degree and the BAS will now be offered fully on-line and in-person when COVID 19 pandemic restrictions are lifted. 

 

GOAL 3 - Develop upper division student/navigation support strategies, conduct outreach, identify and implement new administrative processes, and market the BAS degrees broadly. A dedicated student support specialist was hired to promote the new degree, develop equivalencies and pathways from other colleges, and provide navigation support to students seeking either to complete the BAS at WCC or transfer to the cybersecurity degree at WWU as part of a previously developed transfer degree between the institutions. WCC will accept transfers from any college that offers a two-year IT degree that maps academically with additional requirements in some cases. Transfers from 44 states are accepted; the other six don't allow transfer of online degrees. Official and unofficial articulation agreements/pathways and course equivalencies have been determined for the BAS with 10 regional community colleges. 

 

Goal 4 - Host CyberPatiot competitions in conjunction with cybersecurity camps for local students, and work with regional school districts to ultimately take over these competitions. Efforts to develop cyberpatriot programs at local school districts were unsuccessful due to a variety of factors including concerns for network vulnerability and lack of instructional interest or support at the high schools. To compensate, WCC held numerous cyber camps for high school and middle students each summer throughout the project including a mini-camp for the Lummi Tribe in 2021.

Goal 5 - Ensure industry participation in curriculum and program development and ongoing evaluation.  The CIS program advisory committee represents regional industry and has been actively engaged since the inception of the project in providing review and input to the lower and upper division courses of the BAS, hiring interns, employing graduates and recommending faculty.  They and other industry members of the community have participated in job fairs, resume review, mock interviews and invited talks to describe career opportunities to students.

The broader impacts of this project include the higher level skills that the Whatcom BAS degree (or WWU) graduates now realize.  The growth in numbers of enrollments and graduates has positively impacted the nearby community and beyond (and is accessible to 44 states), by contributing a highly skilled workforce capable or protecting networks at refineries, city municipalities, and across industry sectors. Coursework is mapped to several recognized industry standards including the knowledge units required by the Center of Academic Excellence (CAE) program and the NICE Framework. The replicable model of the BAS degree, navigational support and online degree application, articulation agreements and course equivalencies with other colleges, and cyber camps have been promoted, and are all freely available for download by other faculty, and are regularly disseminated nationally in support of colleges across the nation pursuing cybersecurity program development, growth and enhance pathways.

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2021
Modified by: Corrinne Sande
